q.question: What is the co-pilot currency requirement?
options: 3 take-offs and landings in the last 60 days
At the controls for 3 flights in the last 60 days
At the controls for 3 take-offs and landings in the last 90 days
q.answer: At the controls for 3 take-offs and landings in the last 90 days

q.question: What is the co-pilot currency requirement?
options: 3 take-offs and landings in the last 60 days
At the controls for 3 flights in the last 60 days
At the controls for 3 take-offs and landings in the last 90 days
q.answer: At the controls for 3 take-offs and landings in the last 90 days
q.explanation: To act as a required pilot flight crewmember (including co-pilot/SIC in multi-pilot operations), a pilot must typically meet the Pilot-in-Command (PIC) recent flight experience requirements. This requires the pilot to have performed **3 take-offs and 3 landings** within the preceding **90 days** in the same category, class, and type (if required) of aircraft. They must be the **sole manipulator of the flight controls** during these maneuvers.

q.question: A list to be carried in the aeroplane detailing minimum equipment required must be approved by:
options: no such book is required to be approved by an authority

q.question: A list to be carried in the aeroplane detailing minimum equipment required must be approved by:
options: no such book is required to be approved by an authority
q.explanation: The **Minimum Equipment List (MEL)** is derived from the Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL) provided by the manufacturer. However, the operational MEL, which specifies how an operator can safely fly with inoperative equipment, must be formally approved by the National Aviation Authority (NAA) of the **country of the operator** (the State that issued the Air Operator Certificate or equivalent operating approval).

q.question: Unaccompanied baggage carried by air shall be cleared under a procedure applicable to:
options: accompanied baggage or under a simplified customs procedure similar to other cargo.
q.answer: accompanied baggage or under a simplified customs procedure similar to other cargo.
q.explanation: According to ICAO Annex 9 (Facilitation), unaccompanied baggage should, whenever possible, be cleared under the same procedure applicable to accompanied baggage or under a simplified customs procedure distinct from that normally applicable to other cargo, to ensure efficient processing for the passenger.

What is the purpose of Decision Point Procedure?
options: Reduce contingency fuel to below that required from Decision Point to destination
Reduce landing mass to avoid stressing the aircraft
Carry minimum fuel to increase Traffic Load
q.answer: Reduce contingency fuel to below that required from Decision Point to destination
q.explanation: The Decision Point Procedure allows an operator to reduce the amount of Contingency Fuel required to be carried at the start of the flight. By reducing the fuel load, the aircraft can carry a higher Traffic Load (payload) for a given Maximum Take-Off Mass.

options: Carry minimum fuel to increase Traffic Load
Reduce landing mass to avoid stressing the aircraft
Reduce contingency fuel to below that required from Decision Point to destination

q.question: What is the purpose of Decision Point Procedure?
options: Carry minimum fuel to increase Traffic Load
Reduce landing mass to avoid stressing the aircraft
Reduce contingency fuel to below that required from Decision Point to destination
q.answer: Reduce contingency fuel to below that required from Decision Point to destination

q.question: A pilot suffering from hyperventilation during final approach in poor weather can combat the effects by:
options: going on 100% oxygen and go around
regulating depth and rate of breathing
q.answer: regulating depth and rate of breathing
q.explanation: Hyperventilation is caused by an excessive rate and depth of breathing, which flushes too much carbon dioxide ($CO_2$) from the blood (respiratory alkalosis). The primary method to combat this is to consciously slow down the breathing rate and reduce the depth of breaths to allow $CO_2$ levels to return to normal. While checking oxygen equipment is a good precaution to rule out hypoxia, the specific remedy for hyperventilation is controlling respiration.

options: going on 100% oxygen and go around
slowing the breathing rate, breathing into a paper bag and continuing the approach
increasing the rate of breathing and continuing the approach
increasing the depth of breathing and going around

Refer to Training Manual, Amsterdam page 10-9X. What is the minimum radio altitude for a Cat 2 ILS DME approach to runway 01L?
Refer to Training Manual, Amsterdam page 10-9X. What is the minimum radio altitude for a Cat 2 ILS DME approach to runway 01L?
q.explanation: A **Category II (CAT II)** ILS approach is defined by a Decision Altitude (DA) or Decision Height (DH) lower than 200 ft but no lower than 100 ft. In the absence of a specific chart, the **100 ft Radio Altitude (RA)** is the minimum DH permitted for a standard CAT II approach and is the required answer for this type of general assessment question.

q.question: The take-off mass is:
options: the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass on completion of the refuelling operation
the mass of the aeroplane including everyone and everything contained within it at the start of the take-off run
the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass for take-off but excluding fuel
the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass at the start of the take-off run
q.answer: the mass of the aeroplane including everyone and everything contained within it at the start of the take-off run

options: the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass at the start of the take-off run
the mass of the aeroplane including usable fuel but excluding traffic load
the mass of the aeroplane including everything and everyone contained within it at the start of the take-off run
the maximum mass permitted for take-off

In the N. Hemisphere when flying in the troposphere above the surface friction layer in the polar maritime air mass behind the cold front of a fully developed frontal depression:
options: the wind will tend to veer in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude
the wind will tend to veer in direction with increase of altitude but the speed may remain constant in the lower layers of the atmosphere
the wind speed will reduce progressively with increase of altitude until at about 10000 feet above mean sea level where it will then tend to increase in speed from another direction
the wind will tend to back in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude
q.answer: the wind will tend to back in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude

q.question: In the N. Hemisphere when flying in the troposphere above the surface friction layer in the polar maritime air mass behind the cold front of a fully developed frontal depression:
options: the wind will tend to veer in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude
the wind will tend to veer in direction with increase of altitude but the speed may remain constant in the lower layers of the atmosphere
the wind speed will reduce progressively with increase of altitude until at about 10000 feet above mean sea level where it will then tend to increase in speed from another direction
the wind will tend to back in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude
q.answer: the wind will tend to veer in direction and increase in speed with progressive increase of altitude

q.question: An aircraft starts at position 0410S 17822W and heads true north for 2950 NM, then turns 90 degrees right, and maintains a rhumb line track for 314 kilometres. What is its final position?
q.explanation:
1. **North Leg:** 2950 NM True North is a change of $2950 / 60 = 49^circ 10' $ of Latitude. Final Latitude is $49^circ 10' 	ext{ N} - 04^circ 10' 	ext{ S} = mathbf{45^circ 00' N}$.
2. **East Leg:** Distance is $314 	ext{ km} approx 169.56 	ext{ NM}$. Using the Departure formula ($Delta 	ext{Long} = 	ext{Dep} / cos(	ext{Lat})$):
$Delta 	ext{Long} = 169.56 / cos(45^circ) approx 239.79 	ext{ min} = 4^circ 00' 	ext{ E}$.
3. **Final Longitude:** $178^circ 22' 	ext{ W} - 4^circ 00' 	ext{ E} = mathbf{174^circ 22' W}$.

q.question: An aircraft starts at position 0410S 17822W and heads true north for 2950 NM, then turns 90 degrees right, and maintains a rhumb line track for 314 kilometres. What is its final position?
q.explanation:
1. **North Leg:** 2950 NM True North is a change of $2950 / 60 = 49^circ 10' $ of Latitude. Final Latitude is $49^circ 10' 	ext{ N} - 04^circ 10' 	ext{ S} = mathbf{45^circ 00' N}$.
2. **East Leg:** Distance is $314 	ext{ km} approx 169.56 	ext{ NM}$. Using the Departure formula ($Delta 	ext{Long} = 	ext{Dep} / cos(	ext{Lat})$):
$$Delta 	ext{Long} = 169.56 / cos(45^circ) approx 239.79 	ext{ min} = 4^circ 00' 	ext{ E}$$.
3. **Final Longitude:** $178^circ 22' 	ext{ W} - 4^circ 00' 	ext{ E} = mathbf{174^circ 22' W}$.

q.question: You are heading 080°(T) when you get a range and bearing fix from your AWR (Airborne Weather Radar) on a headland at 185 NM 30° left of the nose. What true bearing do you plot on the chart?
options: 050 from the headland, using the headland's meridian
050 from the headland, using the aircraft's meridian
230 from the headland, using the headland's meridian
230 from the headland, using the aircraft's meridian
q.answer: 230 from the headland, using the aircraft's meridian

230 from the headland, using the aircraft's meridian
q.answer: 230 from the headland, using the headland's meridian

q.question: Where is a compass most effective?
options: About midway between the earth's magnetic poles
In the region of the magnetic South Pole
In the region of the magnetic North Pole
q.answer: About midway between the earth's magnetic poles

q.question: An aircraft at FL370 is required to commence descent at 120 NM from a VOR and to cross the facility at FL130. If the mean GS for the descent is 288 kt, the minimum rate of descent required is:
An aircraft at FL370 is required to commence descent at 120 NM from a VOR and to cross the facility at FL130. If the mean GS for the descent is 288 kt, the minimum rate of descent required is:
q.explanation: 1. **Altitude Change** ($\Delta H$): $37,000 \text{ ft} - 13,000 \text{ ft} = 24,000 \text{ ft}$.\n2. **Time Available** ($T$): $T = \text{Distance} / \text{Speed} = 120 \text{ NM} / 288 \text{ kt} = 0.41666 \text{ hrs}$, or $25 \text{ minutes}$.\n3. **Rate of Descent** (ROD): $\text{ROD} = \Delta H / T = 24,000 \text{ ft} / 25 \text{ min} = \mathbf{960 \text{ ft/min}}$.

q.question: When operating with anti-skid inoperative:

only landing performance will be affected

neither take-off nor landing performance will be affected

options: both landing and performance will be affected

only take-off performance will be affected

q.question: When take-off mass is limited by Vmbe (maximum brake-energy speed), an increase in the uphill slope will:
options: require a decrease in the mass
allow an increase in the mass
q.answer: allow an increase in the mass
q.explanation: For ATPL performance questions, an **increase in uphill slope** generally increases the **Take-Off Distance Required (TODR)** because a component of gravity opposes acceleration. When TODR increases, the safe maximum Take-Off Mass (TOM) must be **decreased** to ensure the aircraft can stop or go within the available field length. While upslope technically reduces the energy absorbed by the brakes in an RTO (allowing for a higher VMBE speed), the overall performance limitation usually shifts back to the required field length, which is negatively affected by the slope.
